details.title: Death toll touches 28 as another riot victim succumbs to injuries
details.content:
One more death was reported at Guru Teg Bahadur (GTB) Hospital, taking the total deaths to 28 in the New Delhi. This is the fifth day since the capital saw massive communal clashes over Citizenship Amendement Act.

(Photo | EPS)

details.title: EDITORIAL | Avoid blame game, restore peace in national capital
details.content: On Sunday, pro-CAA protesters held a counter-demonstration in the vicinity, leading to violence between the two groups. But what started as a pro- and anti-CAA clash soon assumed communal colours, with rioters identifying their victims by their religious denomination. (READ MORE)

details.title: IB staffer Ankit Sharma's body found inside drain; kin say cops did nothing
details.content:
The family had been looking for Ankit after he went missing on Tuesday. Ankit’s mother Sudha Sharma accused the police of inaction. (READ MORE) 

People carry the dead body of 26-year-old Ankit Sharma, an Intelligence Bureau staffer, after retrieving it from a drain in the riot-affected north-east Delhi. (Photo | PTI)

details.title: OPINION | How anti-CAA protests distort the truth
details.content: Articles 5-11 of the Constitution clearly lay down the criteria for citizenship. Several amendments have refined the criteria, notably the Citizenship (Amendment) Act of 2003 that defined an illegal immigrant and disallowed citizenship to their progeny. (READ MORE)

details.title: Recieved 19 calls from North-east Delhi: Fire department
details.content: "Senior officials are inspecting the affected areas. We did not face any resistance this time while carrying out the operations in the violence affected areas of North-east Delhi. We received 19 calls from 12 am till 8 am today from the violence affected areas of North-east Delhi. More than 100 firemen have been deployed. The four fire stations in these areas have been provided with extra fire tenders," says Atul Garg, Director, Fire Department.

details.title: 48 FIRs filed till date: Centre
details.content: Solicitor General Tushar Mehta says 48 FIRs have been lodged till date in relation to arson, looting and the deaths in the Delhi violence.

details.title: RSS leader condemns violence, appeals for peace
details.content: Nobody has right to take law into their hands. The government should ensure peace is restored in riot-hit areas in Delhi, PTI quotes RSS general secretary Suresh 'Bhaiyyaji' Joshi as saying.

details.title: No FIR for hate speech as it won't help restore peace: Delhi Police to HC
details.content: Delhi Police, through the Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, told the High Court that in a conscious decision, they have decided not to file an FIR for hate speech against anyone at this stage as it won't help in restoring peace and normalcy in the national capital. Delhi Police also informed the HC that they have filed 48 FIRs in the violence case.

details.title: HC gives 4 weeks to file counter affidavit
details.content: Delhi High Court gives Centre time till April 13 (4 weeks) to file counter-affidavit to plea seeking FIR against BJP leaders for hate speeches.

details.title: India slams global Islamic body over Delhi violence
details.content:
India on Thursday hit out at the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) for its statement on Delhi violence, saying the comments are factually inaccurate and misleading. details.title: Crime Branch  SITs formed to probe North East Delhi violence
details.content: Two SITs of Crime Branch have been formed under DCP Joy Tirkey and DCP Rajesh Deo. The teams to immediately take over the investigation of the cases connected with North East Delhi violence. BK Singh, Addnl CP Crime Branch to supervise the work of the two teams.

details.content: Shiromani Akali Dal MP Naresh Gujral said on Thursday that the Delhi Police's "inaction" towards protecting the lives and properties of minorities in the national capital is a "reminiscent" of the 1984 anti-Sikh riots. The lawmaker, whose party is a BJP ally, said no one wants a repeat of what happened in 1984.

Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman says Delhi violence, anti-CAA protests have not dampened investor sentiment.

Union Law Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has stated that there is no question of going back on CAA, but government will try to convince people opposing it.
